Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I walked beside my younger brother, our backpacks bouncing as we made our way down Maple Street. It was almost time for the Wednesday evening church service, and I knew how important it was to be there—Pastor Lee always said our presence mattered, not just for worship but for the sense of community. But as we passed the old bakery, my brother winced and grabbed his ankle, stumbling. He’d twisted it badly, and I could see the pain in his eyes. He needed me to help him home, maybe even to the doctor. I felt the weight of my responsibility as his sibling, to make sure he was safe and cared for. But the church bells in the distance reminded me of my other duty, the one to my faith and my church family. I could feel the expectations pulling me in two directions—my brother’s need for me right now, and the call to be present at church, to not let anyone down. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do, torn between the two roles that meant so much to me.
